content.webTitle: Baby Ferouz, born in Brisbane, marks his first birthday in immigration facility

fields.headline: Baby Ferouz, born in Brisbane, marks his first birthday in immigration facility
fields.bodyText: A boy born in Australia but considered an unauthorised arrival by immigration officials has marked his first birthday inside a Darwin detention facility. There were no cakes or candles for Ferouz’s birthday, his father told Guardian Australia, saying it was all he could do to try to raise a smile from his youngest son. The father of three said his family had grown increasingly despondent with the monotony of life in detention and uncertainty about their fates. They wait in legal limbo as lawyers fight to keep Ferouz, who was born in Brisbane but treated as an unauthorised arrival by immigration officials, in Australia. Ferouz’s father, whom Guardian Australia has chosen not to name, spoke by phone through an interpreter on the child’s birthday on Thursday last week. “I wanted to have at least a cake and do something with the whole family, the children and others and make a happy birthday, celebrate his birthday,” he said. “But in here, we don’t have anything actually to do. “So what I did this morning when we woke up, because I can’t celebrate anything here, I just looked at him and gave a laugh to him. That’s it.” A report last year by child refugee advocate group Chilout argued the regime in the centre “destroys the family unit and makes pro-active parenting nearly impossible”. “Children are witnessing the mental anguish of their parents, parents are unable to work, no adult is furthering their education, a parent cannot even make their child’s breakfast,” it said. It quoted a centre staffer: “There are the mental health issues people arrive with and then there are the ones they acquire whilst they’re here.” Ferouz, whose family is from the persecuted Rohingyan minority of Burma, had grown into a playful toddler who was starting to walk, said his father. “Once he starts playing, he feels happy. I take him around inside the camp and go all the way around. You can’t go anywhere else,” he said. But the man said he felt increasingly hopeless, concerned about the mental and physical health of his family after prolonged detention. “When I see my children and my wife, I feel very sad,” he said. “My children are not happy because they’ve been a long time here. If it was one or two months, fine, but it has been more than a year now.” The man said he was particularly worried for Ferouz’s seven-year-old sister who has an intellectual disability and persistent health concerns including stomach problems. His wife has diabetes, exacerbated by the stress of their situation, and problems with her leg. Ferouz himself has had an ulcer on his tongue for a month. “They give some medication but it doesn’t help,” his father said. Concerns about the family’s health are what make him fear a return to Nauru, where immigration staff have repeatedly told him his family are to be sent. “The reason I’m not happy to go to Nauru is my child’s health, she will not have good treatment there,” the man said. “The hospital is very limited, we’ve been to the hospital as well and it’s very difficult to get admitted, get treatment.” Before Ferouz was born, his family were in offshore detention on Nauru. Medical concerns during pregnancy prompted their transfer to Brisbane, where Ferouz was born in the Mater hospital. Ferouz has a Queensland birth certificate but a federal court judge last month ruled his “arrival” in Australia was unauthorised because his parents were asylum seekers without valid visas. A legal team working pro bono, led by Maurice Blackburn’s Murray Watt, has appealed against that decision, which looms as a precedent for about 100 other Australian-born children. Watt said even if the appeal was successful, parts of a new immigration bill before federal parliament would retrospectively overrule the court’s decision. Ferouz still has a citizenship application pending. What made life in Darwin harder to bear, Ferouz’s father said, was that those inside were divided into two groups, the hope-filled and the hopeless. “Some are very happy because they are going outside into the community, and some of them are very sad because they have to go [offshore],” he said. He said it was particularly hard seeing another family who arrived on the same day who were now “very happy and they’re going out”. “But how come we’re hearing all the time ‘you have to go to Nauru’? What’s the difference with us?” According to the Chilout report, the Darwin centre held 338 children, nearly half of all children in detention by the Australian government. That included eight boys without their families and another 50 pregnant women. Watt said the long-term psychiatric harm caused especially to children held in detention had been documented in “many reports from independent doctors”. He said the detention of nearly 800 children, each on average for more than 14 months, had cost taxpayers hundred of millions of dollars – $1m in the case of Ferouz and his family alone. Watt condemned the government’s treatment of the children and called on the federal Senate to block the legislation that would put protection visas out of reach of Ferouz and 100 other Australian-born children. Ferouz’s appeal against the federal court ruling that upheld the federal government’s decision will be heard on 24 November.
